You could call the window via a decision (maybe even in a new category) instead, then no compatch is needed and no vanilla gui file will be touched. KeizerHarm | T4N 8/29/2025 5:50 AM
The head determination jank was an idea based on the fact that head determination is a cultural trait too. So in vanilla it's literally this: head_determination_domain = { type = head_determination head_determination_type = domain } head_determination_herd = { type = head_determination head_determination_type = herd } But you can just put character_modifier, county_modifier, etc blocks in there and it'll work just fine.

KeizerHarm | T4N 9/15/2025 3:20 PM
@joemann you're really going down the wrong track here
3:25 PM
You can't reuse kill_list_window because it expects a CharacterSelectionList datacontext, which is not one we can create. Vanilla gets it from KillListWindow.GetKills and ArtifactKillListWindow.GetKills respectively, and you cannot reuse that because the two window types are types supplied by the hard code only for the respective windows.
3:25 PM
Gui modding is built on globally accessible functions. We don't have the fancy widgets that vanilla uses, we need to patch things together from things like player variables
3:26 PM
So you need to create a new window type
3:27 PM
Probably copypasting most from the contents of the type kill_list_window, but with a lot of adjustments around removing all use of CharacterSelectionList from it.
3:27 PM
It's not going to be trivial to make it match the look of vanilla.
joemann 9/15/2025 3:32 PM
Thanks. I am not sure I am up to that challenge. But you have certainly saved me a lot of time.

2:40 PM
alternatively, you could use hboxes and stretch factors
2:42 PM
basically something like this hbox = { layoutpolicy_horizontal = expanding widget = { layoutpolicy_horizontal = expanding layoutstretchfactor_horizontal = "value 1" } widget = { layoutpolicy_horizontal = expanding layoutstretchfactor_horizontal = "value 2" } widget = { layoutpolicy_horizontal = expanding layoutstretchfactor_horizontal = "value 3" } }
2:42 PM
they would take 100% of the width but share it in proportion to that stretchfactor
2:43 PM
so if the values are 2, 3, 5, first one would take 20%, second 30%, last one 50%

KeizerHarm | T4N 10/9/2025 12:30 PM
Gui modding is not like script modding; we're a lot more limited in what we can do
12:30 PM
To summarise it
12:32 PM
The windows in vanilla (almost) all get some special support directly from the hardcode. That'll be in the form of some data object, usally ending in Window. Like ReligionWindow, SuccessionAppointmentWindow, ActivityListWindow...
12:32 PM
That data object has functions that get the useful information and operations for that window - as vanilla uses it
12:33 PM
There's ReligionWindow.GetReligion, ReligionWindow.GetFaiths, and so on
12:34 PM
Now when we are doing gui modding, inside a vanilla gui window, we can use those too. But that means we're editing the file and there'll be no compatibility with other mods that do. Regardless for most custom functions (like e.g. a spy network) you want to create novel windows.
12:34 PM
And when you are making your own window in your own file, code isn't helping you.
12:34 PM
You'll start from nothing
12:34 PM
So our lifeline is the global functions. The functions that work anywhere because they don't rely on a Window type or on anything derived from it.
12:35 PM
GetPlayer is an example of a global function. So a lot of gui modding just stores things on the player scriptside, and retrieves them guiside with GetPlayer.MakeScope.Var('...')
Pawkkie 10/9/2025 12:35 PM
yeah I have leveraged that a lot as you might expect
12:35 PM
I follow thus far
KeizerHarm | T4N 10/9/2025 12:36 PM
But yeah, the global functions can't give you everything and sometimes you find that all the ways to get the object you want (like SkillItem) are ultimately from one or more Window types. Meaning unless you're editing a vanilla window with that type, you can't get them.
Pawkkie 10/9/2025 12:37 PM
fascinating
KeizerHarm | T4N 10/9/2025 12:37 PM
Sometimes gui needs to do total jank to replicate something that's a oneliner in vanilla
12:37 PM
data_types_uncategorized.txt is the essential file here.

KeizerHarm | T4N 10/9/2025 12:39 PM
That's a non-starter, because you cannot even get a CharacterListItem - the only three functions that produce it are CharacterInteractionConfirmationWindow.GetTopCharacterItem, MatchmakerInteractionWindow.GetTopCharacterItem, SuccessionAppointmentWindow.GetTopCandidate
12:39 PM
All are Window types. So you can't get it.

12:41 PM
You would need to make a script value that duplicates Intrigue and all that modifies it. That's just impossible.

ProfessorHardknocks 10/15/2025 8:38 AM
Is there like a "Day 1" to fire off once the character is chosen? That is what I was trying to go for.
Pep 10/15/2025 8:39 AM
on_game_start_after_lobby is day zero wrt to game play. After that when you take the game of pause multiple systems start ticking.
8:39 AM
So if you wanted to do anything to the player before they gain control then on_game_start_after_lobby would be the place.
8:40 AM
Typically you would either do everything in that tick or trigger an event or on_action from there with a one day delay.
8:42 AM
Any events or on_action triggered with a one day delay will start executing on the next day after you take the game off pause.

YAGPDB.xyz BOT 10/15/2025 8:54 AM
Where's the documentation? How will I know what the script can do and what the rules are?
The CK3 scripting language is not a formal programming language; it's being developed one feature at a time with little regard for consistency, and every update introduces new capabilities. There is no complete documentation and there likely never will be. But there are a number of helpful sources of information:
  • The most up-to-date resource is the script logs: by running the console command script_docs in game, a number of different files are put in your logs folder that list all available triggers, effects, modifiers, and more. For gui modding use dump_data_types. Find the logs folder here:
    • Documents/Paradox Interactive/Crusader Kings III/logs on Windows
    • "$HOME/.local/share/Paradox Interactive/Crusader Kings III/logs" on Linux
  • Many folders in vanilla will have files ending in .info that explain the allowed fields and properties of the type of entity in that folder. These are also, usually, up-to-date.
  • The CK3 Wiki is being maintained by volunteers and has many pages on specific subjects. You are most likely to find outdated information here, but also the most enlightening explanations of the principles behind certain systems.
  • Lastly there's us, the Coop. Feel free to ask questions if you're having trouble figuring anything out! But do first check the above three sources or we'll likely keep barraging you with this command instead :)

Pep 10/24/2025 11:54 AM
But you're still using create_artifact_bow_effect right? This is in the artifact custom loc ArtifactBowType = { type = character text = { # trigger = { scope:bow_type ?= flag:artifact_bow_type_longbow } localization_key = bow_longbow_inspiration_description } text = { # trigger = { scope:bow_type ?= flag:artifact_bow_type_composite } localization_key = bow_composite_inspiration_description } text = { # trigger = { scope:bow_type ?= flag:artifact_bow_type_crossbow } localization_key = bow_crossbow_inspiration_description } text = { # trigger = { scope:bow_type ?= flag:artifact_bow_type_bow } localization_key = bow_bow_inspiration_description fallback = yes } } So just do something like create_artifact_bow_effect = { OWNER = scope:local_ruler CREATOR = scope:dummy_gender SET_BOW_TYPE = flag:artifact_bow_type_crossbow } or set the flag to flag:no (edited)

King Spork 10/25/2025 2:39 PM

Pep 10/28/2025 7:01 AM
That's trickier, I don't think I've ever directly pulled a story from a list of stories, mostly wherever I have used stories they are nested in player or global variables, so am unsure how you would get the story from the datamodel. So typically I would do something like datacontext = "[GetPlayer.MakeScope.Var('my_story').Story]" Where the variable my_story on the player holds a story. So for a datamodel, I guess you could try something like datacontext = [Scope.Story] Then in your item, instead of [CHARACTER.<something>] you address the story with something like [Story.MakeScope.Var('some_variable')] No guarantees that works though, it's all untested ad-hoc gui (edited)
7:02 AM
If datacontext = [Scope.Story] doesn't work then try the dubious datacontext = [Scope.MakeScope.Story] (edited)

IsaBeau
Is it possible to add something like an Editbox to a window, where you can enter a number and then via button press a variable gets set to that value ? (edited)
Pep 11/5/2025 2:28 PM
UI doesn't have string input, so not easily. You can mess about with the change name feature from the rename a child event but it is very painful to do. WOK has an example that names a series of books you can look at. When it comes to numbers, I just use a set of gui buttons and a label to display the current value of a variable, then use a series of <, <<, >, >> buttons to increment/decrement by +/- 1 and +/- 10

Hey so I'm new to doing math on GUI elements - usually I do it in script but that isn't an option here. How could I do this formula? I know there are data types for divide, modulo, and subtract... but I'm not sure how to get the order of operations correct? (NOTE: Use case is this: I have a 32 bit number being passed as $VALUE$. I need to grab the top 12 bits of it) (edited)
Jaco_Daan | LotR Realms 11/30/2025 10:16 PM
I believe this should be correct: Divide_int32(Subtract_int32(N, Modulo_int32(N , '(int32)4096')), '(int32)4096')
10:17 PM
And if N is a value stored as a variable, you'll also need to do: FixedPointToInt( N ), as IIRC variables return CFixedPoint

Five | Rank & File 12/1/2025 10:20 AM
Iâ€™m not sure I follow your meaning
Dr Tobbzn | Way of Kings 12/1/2025 10:21 AM
Do you know what a fixed point number is?
10:21 AM
It's an integer that is represented in some shifted format with some fixed number of decimals
10:22 AM
So if you have a fixed point that's shifted by 1 decimal point then the integer 4 represents the number 0.4
10:22 AM
If you're shifting by 3 decimals then the integer 4 represents the number 0.004
10:22 AM
And so on
10:23 AM
They used to use CFixedPoints with 3 decimals, then I think they upgraded it to 6 decimals, and I heard some people talk about how it now supports 9 decimals
